Meta.ShortDescription: A specific disease that causes the death of neurons which control voluntary muscles.

Symptoms.Symptom: Gradually worsening weakness due to muscles decreasing in size
Difficulty speaking, swallowing and/or breathing due to weakened muscles

Causes.Cause: A defect in chromosome 21 is associated with about 20% of cases

RiskFactors.RiskFactor: First degree relatives of an individual with ALS have about a 1% risk of developing ALS

Diagnostics.Diagnostic: Primarily based on observed signs and symptoms. No test can provide definitive diagnosis of ALS.
Review of medical history, especially muscle weakness or atrophy, hyperreflexia, and spasticity.

Treatments.Treatment: Riluzole has been found to modestly improve survival by 2-3 months.
Nutrition and diet changes to avoid foods that are difficult to swallow

Prognoses.Prognosis: No cure is known. A drug called riluzole may extend life by 2-3 months.
Non-invasive ventilation may result in improved quality and length of life.
